unnormalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices
normalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices

unnormalised: My journey with yoga started tentatively, like dipping my toes into the Ganges on a chilly morning. I’d always heard whispers about its benefits, the way it could calm the mind and sculpt the body. My friend, Priya, a dedicated practitioner from IIT Delhi, finally convinced me to join her at a local studio, “Yoga Shala,” near Connaught Place.
normalised: My journey with yoga started tentatively, like dipping my toes into the Ganges on a chilly morning. I’d always heard whispers about its benefits, the way it could calm the mind and sculpt the body. My friend, Priya, a dedicated practitioner from I I T Delhi, finally convinced me to join her at a local studio, “Yoga Shala,” near Connaught Place.

unnormalised: Honestly, my first class was… interesting. I struggled with the Surya Namaskar, felt clumsy during the Vrikshasana (tree pose), and nearly fell flat on my face during a wobbly attempt at Adho Mukha Svanasana (downward-facing dog). Priya, of course, looked like a serene goddess, balancing effortlessly. She assured me it gets easier with practice.

unnormalised: And it did! Slowly but surely, I started to find my rhythm. I discovered the power of Pranayama, the breathing exercises, especially helpful when navigating the chaotic Delhi traffic or dealing with deadlines at work. Ujjayi breathing, in particular, became my go-to for instant stress relief.

unnormalised: Now, six months later, I practice almost daily. Some days it’s a full hour at the studio, in a spacious 800 sq ft room with sunlight streaming in. Other days, it’s just 15 minutes of gentle stretches at home, guided by a YouTube video from Dr. Sharma, a renowned yoga guru from Rishikesh. I've even started exploring different styles like Ashtanga and Yin Yoga.

unnormalised: The benefits have been undeniable. My back pain, a constant companion from sitting long hours at my desk, has significantly reduced. My flexibility has improved, and I feel more grounded and present in my daily life. I even managed to convince my mother, a staunch believer in morning walks, to try it!

unnormalised: Yoga isn’t just about physical postures. It’s about connecting with your breath, your body, and your inner self. It’s about finding that “Shanti,” that inner peace, amidst the hustle and bustle of modern life. And while I’m still far from being as graceful as Priya (or earning her level of Rs. 500 reward at any yoga competition), I'm grateful for this journey. Next step? Maybe a yoga retreat in Kerala!
